In contrast, the EIS data of CoSSe-YS electrode after 100 cycles revealed a higher resistance, which is likely attributable to the thick SEI layer due to continuous structural degradation during repeated cycling.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="fig6"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0378775324011388-gr6.jpg" height="533" alt="Fig. 6" aria-describedby="cap0035"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0378775324011388-gr6_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (1MB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (1MB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0378775324011388-gr6.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cap0035"><p id="fspara0035"><span class="label">Fig. 6</span>. CV curves of (a) CoSSe-YS and (b) CoSSe-YS@C electrodes, and (c) their initial discharge/charge curves. Electrochemical properties of CoSSe-YS, CoSSe-YS@C, CoS-YS, and CoSe-YS electrodes: (d) Rate performances, (e) Rate performance of CoSSe-YS@C at various current densities (0.2–15&nbsp;A&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup>), (f) Cycle performances at a current density of 0.2&nbsp;A&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup>, and (g–j) their SEM images after 100 cycles.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0105">To explore the impact of heteroatom doping in CoSSe-YS anode, a phase-pure cobalt sulfoselenide yolk-shell microsphere (referred to as P-CoSSe-YS) was fabricated using identical spray pyrolysis and post-treatment processes. For this, the spray solution was made by dissolving same concentration of cobalt salt and sucrose, without the addition of any other heteroatoms. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S12a</span></span></a> and b show that the synthesized P-CoSSe-YS exhibited a yolk-shell structure, and its XRD data (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S12c</span></span></a>), similar to that of CoSSe-YS, revealed peaks shifted to the right compared to Co<sub>0.85</sub>Se (PDF #52–1008). However, compared to CoSSe-YS, P-CoSSe-YS's XRD peaks were slightly shifted towards higher diffraction angles, as shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S12d</span></span></a>. This suggests that the doping with other metals, which are byproducts from the recycling process, leads to lattice expansion in the cobalt sulfoselenide structure. As reported in the previous literature, this expanded lattice structure benefits the rapid diffusion of Na-ions, thus enhancing the material's electrochemical properties [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib61" name="bbib61" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib61"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">61</span></span></a>]. Consequently, as shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S13</span></span></a>, P-CoSSe-YS exhibits a significant difference in rate capability compared to CoSSe-YS. At a 5&nbsp;A&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup>, P-CoSSe-YS represented a reversible discharge capacity of 233&nbsp;mA&nbsp;h&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup>. This indicates that heteroatom doping within the cobalt sulfoselenide nanocrystals markedly enhances the rate performance.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0110">To investigate the practical application for the developed material, a full cell test was conducted to evaluate its performance under realistic operating conditions. Prussian blue (PB) was selected as the cathode material, and its synthesis process was referenced from the previous study [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib62" name="bbib62" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib62"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">62</span></span></a>]. As shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S14</span></span></a>, the prepared PB exhibited micro-sized cube morphologies, and the X-ray diffraction (XRD) data showed sharp peaks corresponding to the face-centered cubic phase, confirming the successful synthesis of the PB cathode. Firstly, the half-cell test of the PB cathode was conducted, as depicted in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S15a and b</span></span></a>. The potential profile of the PB cathode exhibited distinct potential plateaus during the charging/discharging processes, which are consistent with typical PB cathode behavior [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib62" name="bbib62" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib62"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">62</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib63" name="bbib63" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib63"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">63</span></span></a>]. At a current density of 0.1&nbsp;A&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup>, the initial charge capacity was only 10&nbsp;mA&nbsp;h&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup>, attributed to the relatively low content of sodium-ions in the as-prepared PB cathode. Starting from the second cycle, the charge and discharge capacities were 126 and 117&nbsp;mA&nbsp;h&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup>, respectively, demonstrating a capacity retention of 99.6&nbsp;% over 50 cycles. Before assembling the full cell, the PB cathode and CoSSe-YS@C anode underwent 2 pre-cycles to address the low sodium-ion content in the fresh PB cathode and mitigate capacity loss during SEI formation in the initial cycle. As shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S15c and d</span></span></a>, the full cell exhibited a high initial charge capacity of 124&nbsp;mA&nbsp;h&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup> and a high initial Coulombic efficiency of 96&nbsp;%, attributable to the pre-cycling process. Furthermore, the full cell showed stable cycling performance over 20 cycles at a current density of 0.1&nbsp;A&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup>, indicating the promising potential of the developed anode for practical applications.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0115">To investigate the resistance of cobalt sulfoselenide during the initial discharge and charge process, in-situ EIS was conducted at a 0.1&nbsp;A&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup> across the potential range of 0.001–3.0&nbsp;V, illustrated in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig7" name="bfig7" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig7"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 7</span></span></a>. The Nyquist plots, detected at particular potentials during the initial cycles, are displayed in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig7" name="bfig7" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig7"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 7</span></span></a>a and b. These plots reflect the contributions from the solution resistance (R<sub>s</sub>), the interfacial layer related to the Solid Electrolyte Interphase (SEI) layer (R<sub>sei</sub>), and the charge transfer resistance (R<sub>ct</sub>). The changes in the total resistance (R<sub>tot</sub>&nbsp;=&nbsp;R<sub>s</sub>&nbsp;+&nbsp;R<sub>sei</sub>&nbsp;+&nbsp;R<sub>ct</sub>) during the first cycle, captured by in-situ EIS at selected potentials, are indicated by the colored dots in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig7" name="bfig7" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig7"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 7</span></span></a>c and d. During the initial discharging process, the two electrodes demonstrated a significant reduction in R<sub>tot</sub> until 1.0&nbsp;V. This phenomenon is likely attributed to aging of sodium ions, indicating gradual electrolyte penetration during the initial stage of the discharging process [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib64" name="bbib64" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib64"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">64</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib65" name="bbib65" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib65"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">65</span></span></a>]. As the discharging process continued in subsequent stages, the volume expansion resulting from the electrochemical reaction of CoSSe and the generation of SEI layers contributed to an increase in electrode resistance [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib13" name="bbib13" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib13"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">13</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib66" name="bbib66" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib66"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">66</span></span></a>]. However, the R<sub>tot</sub> values were gradually decreased as the potential decreased from 1 to 0.001&nbsp;V. It can be attributed to the conversion of large CoSSe nanocrystals to ultrafine metallic Co nanocrystals with Na<sub>2</sub>S/Na<sub>2</sub>Se matrix during the initial sodiation process [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib67" name="bbib67" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib67"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">67</span></span></a>]. This transformation had a more substantial effect on the total resistance of the electrode compared to the previously mentioned reasons, leading to a gradual decrease in R<sub>tot</sub> values. Notably, during the aging process until 1.0&nbsp;V, CoSSe-YS@C electrode demonstrated higher resistance values due to the presence of additional carbon layers. However, this carbon component plays a crucial role in alleviating the structural strain arising from volume expansion. Consequently, CoSSe-YS@C electrode showed more stable R<sub>tot</sub> variation during the conversion reaction at 0.8&nbsp;V–0.001&nbsp;V. At the subsequent charging process, the R<sub>tot</sub> of two electrodes were continuously decreased, possibly owing to the partial dissolution of SEI layers and the volume shrink induced by desodiation process [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib68" name="bbib68" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib68"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">68</span></span></a>]. Moreover, the formation of heterointerfaced nanocomposites <em>via</em> the conversion reaction from metallic Co to Co<sub>9</sub>S<sub>8</sub> and Co<sub>0.85</sub>Se enhanced the electrochemical kinetics, leading to a further decrease in R<sub>tot</sub> after 2.0&nbsp;V [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib13" name="bbib13" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib13"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">13</span></span></a>]. The variations in sodium-ion diffusion coefficients (D<sub>Na+</sub>) of the two electrodes were calculated from the sloping lines in the low-frequency domain using the following equation:<span class="display"><span id="ufd2" class="formula"><span><em>D</em><sub><em>Na+</em></sub>&nbsp;=&nbsp;0.5 (<em>RT</em>/<em>Sn</em><sup>2</sup><em>F</em><sup>2</sup><em>C</em>σ)<sup>2</sup>,</span></span></span></div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="fig7"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0378775324011388-gr7.jpg" height="612" alt="Fig. 7" aria-describedby="cap0040"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0378775324011388-gr7_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (973KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (973KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0378775324011388-gr7.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cap0040"><p id="fspara0040"><span class="label">Fig. 7</span>. In-situ EIS analysis of CoSSe-YS@C and CoSSe-YS electrodes in the initial cycle: (a,b) Nyquist plots of CoSSe-YS@C and CoSSe-YS electrodes measured at preselected potentials, (c,d) in-situ EIS graphs (R<sub>tot</sub> vs potential), and (e,f) variations in sodium-ion diffusion coefficients calculated from in-situ EIS data.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0120">The information of parameter values can be found in the previous literature [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib69" name="bbib69" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib69"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">69</span></span></a>]. As shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig7" name="bfig7" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig7"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 7</span></span></a>e and f, both electrodes exhibited a similar behavior during the initial cycle. During the initial discharging process, the S doped CoSSe crystals underwent a transformation into ultrafine Co nanocrystals distributed within a Na<sub>2</sub>S/Na<sub>2</sub>Se composite matrix. These species have higher sodium-ion diffusivity compared to CoSSe due to lower crystallinity and weaker Na–S/Na–Se ionic bonds [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib66" name="bbib66" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib66"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">66</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib70" name="bbib70" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib70"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">70</span></span></a>]. Specifically, the hetero-interface of Na<sub>2</sub>S/Na<sub>2</sub>Se serves as a rapid pathway for the diffusion of sodium-ions, further enhancing the sodium-ion diffusivity throughout the sodiation process [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib59" name="bbib59" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib59"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">59</span></span></a>]. Consequently, the D<sub>Na&nbsp;+</sub>&nbsp;values for both electrodes showed a gradual increase during the sodiation process, while demonstrating a steady decrease during the desodiation. It is noteworthy that, compared to CoSSe-YS electrode, in the discharging process, CoSSe-YS@C electrode displayed a rapid increase in D<sub>Na&nbsp;+</sub>&nbsp;starting from the conversion reaction around 0.8&nbsp;V of CoSSe, and maintained a stable D<sub>Na&nbsp;+</sub>&nbsp;variation until 1.8&nbsp;V in the charging process before the regeneration of Co<sub>0.85</sub>Se/Co<sub>9</sub>S<sub>8</sub>. This could be ascribed to the additional carbon layer surrounding the CoSSe crystals, which effectively accommodates the structural strain induced by the phase transition during the cycling process.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0125">To clarify the sodium ion diffusion kinetics during the initial cycle, the galvanostatic intermittent titration technique (GITT) analysis was applied, as depicted in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig8" name="bfig8" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig8"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 8</span></span></a>, during the initial cycle. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig8" name="bfig8" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig8"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 8</span></span></a>a and b illustrate the profiles obtained from the GITT analysis, conducted at a 0.1&nbsp;A&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup>, with a pulse time of 10&nbsp;min and a relaxation time of 60&nbsp;min. The sodium ion diffusion coefficient (D<sub>Na+</sub>) can be calculated using the following equation:<span class="display"><span id="ufd3" class="formula"><span class="math"><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><msub is="true"><mi is="true">D</mi><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">N</mi><mi is="true"><mi is="true">N</mi><mi is="true">a</mi><mo linebreak="badbreak" is="true">+</mo></mrow></msub><mo linebreak="badbreak" is="true">=</mo><mn is="true">4</mn><mo linebreak="badbreak" is="true">/</mo><mi is="true">π</mi><mi is="true">τ</mi><msup is="true"><mrow is="true"><mo stretchy="true" is="true">(</mo><mfrac is="true"><mrow is="true"><msub is="true"><mi is="true">m</mi><mi is="true">B</mi></msub><msub is="true"><mi is="true">V</mi><mi is="true">M</mi></msub></mrow><mrow is="true"><msub is="true"><mi is="true">M</mi><mi is="true">B</mi></msub><mi is="true">S</mi></mrow></mfrac><mo stretchy="true" is="true">)</mo></mrow><mn is="true">2</mn></msup><mo is="true">∙</mo><msup is="true"><mrow is="true"><mo stretchy="true" is="true">(</mo><mfrac is="true"><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">Δ</mo><msub is="true"><mi is="true">E</mi><mi is="true">s</mi></msub></mrow><msub is="true"><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">Δ</mo><mi is="true">E</mi></mrow><mi is="true">τ</mi></msub></mfrac><mo stretchy="true" is="true">)</mo></mrow><mn is="true">2</mn></msup></mrow></math></script></span></span></span></div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="fig8"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0378775324011388-gr8.jpg" height="395" alt="Fig. 8" aria-describedby="cap0045"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0378775324011388-gr8_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (654KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (654KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0378775324011388-gr8.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cap0045"><p id="fspara0045"><span class="label">Fig. 8</span>. (A,b) GITT potential profiles for (a) CoSSe-YS@C and (b) CoSSe-YS electrodes in the initial cycle and the corresponding sodium-ion diffusion coefficients for (c) CoSSe-YS@C and (d) CoSSe-YS.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0130">The relevant parameter values have been reported in previous study [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib71" name="bbib71" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib71"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">71</span></span></a>]. As depicted in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig8" name="bfig8" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig8"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 8</span></span></a>c and d, both electrodes showed a gradual increase in D<sub>Na&nbsp;+</sub>&nbsp;values during the discharging process, followed by a gradual decrease during the charging process. Although the D<sub>Na&nbsp;+</sub>&nbsp;values obtained from GITT and EIS measurements generally exhibited parallel trends, they presented distinct differences in absolute values. Furthermore, a slight difference in the trend was observed when comparing <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig7" name="bfig7" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig7"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 7</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig8" name="bfig8" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig8"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 8</span></span></a>c. This difference might be due to the inherent uncertainties in both techniques, as reported in the previous literature [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib72" name="bbib72" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib72"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">72</span></span></a>]. However, it's important to highlight that the D<sub>Na&nbsp;+</sub>&nbsp;values obtained <em>via</em> the GITT method also reflected increased Na-ion diffusivity due to the formation of a Na<sub>2</sub>S/Na<sub>2</sub>Se heterostructure, which contributes to the enhanced rate capabilities of cobalt sulfoselenide anodes.</div></section><section id="sec4"><h2 id="sectitle0060" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">4. Conclusions</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0135">In this research, we introduced a novel fabrication procedure for heteroatom-doped cobalt sulfoselenide yolk-shell microsphere. By employing a leaching process, spray pyrolysis, and heat treatment, yolk-shell structured microspheres comprising heteroatom-doped cobalt sulfoselenide nanocrystals were successfully synthesized. The reaction mechanism of cobalt sulfoselenide in sodium-ion batteries was thoroughly investigated through various analyses. These analyses confirmed that the formation of heterostructures, induced by the conversion reaction of cobalt sulfoselenide, leads to improved electrochemical performance. Moreover, the heteroatom doping, a result of the recycling process, leads to the expansion of cobalt sulfoselenide lattice structures, enhancing Na-ion diffusion kinetics. The carbon layer on the anode surface, as a result of pitch solution infiltration, can effectively accommodate volumetric stress throughout repetitive cycling. Consequently, the heteroatom-doped cobalt sulfoselenide yolk-shell microsphere anode demonstrated outstanding cycling stability alongside remarkable rate performance for sodium-ion batteries. This novel synthesis method and the strategies for understanding the conversion reaction mechanism could be expected to apply developing various energy storage materials.</div></section><section id="sec5"><h2 id="sectitle0065" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">CRediT authorship contribution statement</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0140"><strong>Yeong Beom Kim:</strong> Writing – original draft, Investigation, Formal analysis, Data curation. <strong>Tae Ha Kim:</strong> Writing – original draft, Investigation, Formal analysis, Data curation. <strong>Seulgi Kim:</strong> Methodology, Investigation, Formal analysis. <strong>Seungo Jeong:</strong> Methodology, Investigation, Formal analysis. <strong>Yun Chan Kang:</strong> Writing – review &amp; editing, Supervision. <strong>Dongju Lee:</strong> Writing – review &amp; editing, Writing – original draft, Supervision. <strong>Gi Dae Park:</strong> Writing – review &amp; editing, Writing – original draft, Supervision, Conceptualization.</div></section></div><section id="coi0010"><h2 id="sectitle0070" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Declaration of competing interest</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0145">The authors declare that they have no known competing financial interests or personal relationships that could have appeared to influence the work reported in this paper.</div></section><section id="ack0010"><h2 id="sectitle0075" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Acknowledgments</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0150">This work was supported by a <span id="gs1">National Research Foundation of Korea</span> (NRF) grant funded by the Korea government (<span id="gs3">MEST</span>) (NRF-<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#gs3"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">2022R1F1A1070886</span></span></a>). batteries</div></div><div class="host u-font-sans">ACS Nano, 13 (2019), pp. 3054-3062</div><div class="ReferenceLinks u-font-sans"><span class="link lazy-third-party-pdf-link"><span></span></span><a data-aa-button="sd:product:journal:article:location=references:type=anchor:name=citation-name"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[72]</span></span></a></span><span class="reference" id="sref72"><div class="contribution"><div class="authors u-font-sans">Y.-C. Chien, H. Liu, A.S. Menon, W.R. Brant, D. Brandell, M.J. Lacey</div><div id="ref-id-sref72" class="title text-m">Rapid determination of solid-state diffusion coefficients in Li-based batteries via intermittent current interruption method</div></div><div class="host u-font-sans">Nat. Commun., 14 (2023), p. 2289</div><div class="ReferenceLinks u-font-sans"><a class="anchor link anchor-primary" href="https://www.scopus.com/inward/record.url?eid=2-s2.0-85153543642&amp;partnerID=10&amp;rel=R3.0.0" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer" aria-describedby="ref-id-sref72"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">View in Scopus</span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 8 8" height="20" aria-label="Opens in new window" class="icon icon-arrow-up-right-tiny href="https://scholar.google.com/scholar_lookup?title=Rapid%20determination%20of%20solid-state%20diffusion%20coefficients%20in%20Li-based%20batteries%20via%20intermittent%20current%20interruption%20method&amp;publication_year=2023&amp;author=Y.-C.%20Chien&amp;author=H.%20Liu&amp;author=A.S.%20Menon&amp;author=W.R.%20Brant&amp;author=D.%20Brandell&amp;author=M.J.%20Lacey" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer" aria-describedby="ref-id-sref72"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Google Scholar</span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 8 8" height="20" aria-label="Opens in new window" class="icon icon-arrow-up-right-tiny arrow-external-link"><path d="M1.12949 2.1072V1H7V6.85795H5.89111V2.90281L0.784057 8L0 7.21635L5.11902 2.1072H1.12949Z"></path></svg></span></a></div></span></li></ol></section></section></div><div id="section-cited-by"><section aria-label="Cited by" class="ListArticles preview"><div class="PageDivider"></div><header id="citing-articles-header"><h2 class="u-h4 u-margin-l-ver u-font-serif">Cited by (4)</h2></header><div aria-describedby="citing-articles-header"><div class="citing-articles u-margin-l-bottom"><ul><li class="ListArticleItem u-margin-l-bottom"><div class="sub-heading u-margin-xs-bottom"><h3 class="u-font-serif" id="citing-articles-article-0-title"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="/science/article/pii/S0927775725001931"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Synthesis for TiN-MXene-Co@CNTs/S with high electrochemical performance</span></span></a></h3><div>2025, Colloids and Surfaces A: Physicochemical and Engineering Aspects</div></div><div class="buttons"><button class="button-link button-link-primary button-link-icon-right" type="button" data-aa-button="sd:product:journal:article:location=citing-articles:type=view-details" aria-describedby="citing-articles-article-0-title" aria-controls="citing-articles-article-0" aria-expanded="false"><span class="button-link-text-container"><span class="button-link-text">Show abstract</span></span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 92 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-down"><path d="M1 51l7-7 38 38 38-38 7 7-45 45z"></path></svg></button></div><div class="u-display-none" aria-hidden="true"><div class="abstract u-margin-xs-top u-margin-m-bottom u-font-serif" id="reference-abstract"><div class="u-margin-ver-m"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="sp0045">Transition metal sulfides (TMSs), due to their low cost, high theoretical capacity, and rich redox reactions, have become a research focus as anode materials for sodium-ion batteries (SIBs). However, problems such as low electrical conductivity, slow kinetic reactions, and irreversible volume changes significantly hinder their practical application. Through heterogeneous interface engineering, it is possible to improve substantially material reactivity, shorten ion diffusion paths, and enhance the structural stability of the materials, thereby overcoming these challenges. In this study, we have innovatively constructed a unique three-dimensional conductive network via in situ growing carbon nanotubes (CNTs) that encapsulate Co<sub>9</sub>S<sub>8</sub>/CoS nanoparticles on TiN-MXene nanosheets. The formation of the TiN-MXene-CNTs heterointerface enhances electrical conductivity and provides sufficient internal void space to accommodate volume expansion effectively. Furthermore, due to its high specific surface area and efficient electron transport pathways, the pseudocapacitive-controlled process plays a significant role in the electrochemical sodium storage of TiN-MXene-Co@CNTs/S. As a result, TiN-MXene-Co@CNTs/S exhibits exceptional performance, demonstrating a high specific capacity of 629.3 mA h g⁻¹ at 0.1 A g⁻¹, good cycling stability with a capacity of 303.4 mA h g⁻¹ after 100 cycles at 0.1 A g⁻¹, and excellent rate capability of 235.5 mA h g⁻¹ at 5 A g⁻¹. EIS, GITT, and CV tests further confirm its superior dynamic performance. Remarkably, the NVP||TiN-MXene-Co@CNTs/S full-cell battery setup maintains a capacity of 177.8 mA h g<sup>−1</sup> after 80 cycles at a current density of 0.1 A g<sup>−1</sup>, highlighting its promising application potential.</div></div></div></div></li><li class="ListArticleItem u-margin-l-bottom"><div class="sub-heading u-margin-xs-bottom"><h3 class="u-font-serif" id="citing-articles-article-1-title"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="/science/article/pii/S0378775325001296"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Coupling of FeS&lt;inf&gt;2-x&lt;/inf&gt;Se&lt;inf&gt;x&lt;/inf&gt; nanoparticles and foam-like carbon superstructure to achieve high-density electron flow for enhanced sodium storage performance</span></span></a></h3><div>2025, Journal of Power Sources</div></div><div class="buttons"><button class="button-link button-link-primary button-link-icon-right" type="button" data-aa-button="sd:product:journal:article:location=citing-articles:type=view-details" aria-describedby="citing-articles-article-1-title" aria-controls="citing-articles-article-1" aria-expanded="false"><span class="button-link-text-container"><span class="button-link-text">Show abstract</span></span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 92 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-down"><path d="M1 51l7-7 38 38 38-38 7 7-45 45z"></path></svg></button></div><div class="u-display-none" aria-hidden="true"><div class="abstract u-margin-xs-top u-margin-m-bottom u-font-serif" id="reference-abstract"><div class="u-margin-ver-m"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="abspara0010">The advantage of FeS<sub>2</sub> in sodium storage is constrained by its poor inherent conductivity and unstable electrochemical activity. In this work, the hierarchical structure, FeS<sub>2-x</sub>Se<sub>x</sub> nanoparticles with high activity encapsulated into the foam-like carbon network, are fabricated by in-situ chelation/self-crosslinking and synchronous sulfurization/selenization strategies. Inside, the incorporation of Se into FeS<sub>2</sub> markedly changes the local electron distribution around the Fe atoms and improves the intrinsic conductivity of FeS<sub>2</sub>. Outside, S, Se codoped foam-like carbon networks are evenly wrapped on the surface of FeS<sub>2-x</sub>Se<sub>x</sub> nanoparticles, which accelerate the diffusion of internal charges into the electrolyte. Excitingly, the Se-replaced FeS<sub>2-x</sub>Se<sub>x</sub> nanoparticles and carbon shell established an unobstructed pathway through robust Fe-S-C and Fe-Se-C bond connections, realizing the transmission of more charge transfer, and finally forming a high-density electron flow. This powerful charge transfer mode from the inside out realizes an overall conductivity improvement of the materials and markedly enhances the rate performance. Moreover, the obtained FeS<sub>2-x</sub>Se<sub>x</sub> nanoparticles ensure high electrochemical activity, and the external carbon layer effectively manages the volume expansion during the sodium storage process. As expected, the FeS<sub>2-x</sub>Se<sub>x</sub>@SSe/C(5:1) exhibits a high capacity (603.73 mAh g<sup>−1</sup>&nbsp;at 1&nbsp;A&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup> over 600 cycles), outstanding rate capability, and cycle performance (225 mAh g<sup>−1</sup>&nbsp;at 3&nbsp;A&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup> over 5231 cycles) for sodium-ion batteries.</div></div></div></div></li><li class="ListArticleItem u-margin-l-bottom"><div class="sub-heading u-margin-xs-bottom"><h3 class="u-font-serif" id="citing-articles-article-2-title"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="/science/article/pii/S235294072500006X"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Bifunctional engineering to construct N, S-doped hard carbon for superior sodium storage</span></span></a></h3><div>2025, Applied Materials Today</div></div><div class="buttons"><button class="button-link button-link-primary button-link-icon-right" type="button" data-aa-button="sd:product:journal:article:location=citing-articles:type=view-details" aria-describedby="citing-articles-article-2-title" aria-controls="citing-articles-article-2" aria-expanded="false"><span class="button-link-text-container"><span class="button-link-text">Show abstract</span></span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 92 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-down"><path d="M1 51l7-7 38 38 38-38 7 7-45 45z"></path></svg></button></div><div class="u-display-none" aria-hidden="true"><div class="abstract u-margin-xs-top u-margin-m-bottom u-font-serif" id="reference-abstract"><div class="u-margin-ver-m"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="spara007">Boosting the performance of hard carbon anodes in sodium-ion batteries, it is essential to develop methods that enhance both their capacity and rate capability. A promising strategy to achieve this is heteroatom doping, which substantially improves the sodium storage potential of hard carbon. In this research, nitrogen and sulfur (N, S) co-doped hard carbons were prepared using a simple two-step carbonization method. By employing bifunctional engineering, which integrates heteroatom doping with the creation of pore structures, the N, S co-doped hard carbon, exhibited exceptional sodium storage characteristics. These include a high reversible capacity of 364.2 mAh g<sup>–1</sup> at 0.1 A g<sup>–1</sup>, an excellent rate capability of 198.7 mAh g<sup>–1</sup> at 10 A g<sup>–1,</sup> stable cycling with a capacity of 190.2 mAh g<sup>–1</sup> at 1 A g<sup>–1</sup> after 2000 cycles, and strong low-temperature performance at 0 °C. The combined effect of nitrogen and sulfur doping expands the interlayer spacing within the hard carbon, facilitating faster sodium ion insertion and extraction. Moreover, pore formation during the heating process generates additional active sites for sodium storage. This study presents a straightforward and efficient approach to improving sodium storage capacity across the full voltage range of hard carbon materials. The method delivers substantial advancements for sodium-ion battery technology, enhancing its overall performance and practicality.</div></div></div></div></li><li class="ListArticleItem u-margin-l-bottom"><div class="sub-heading u-margin-xs-bottom"><h3 class="u-font-serif" id="citing-articles-article-3-title"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="https://doi.org/10.1039/d4nj03543g" target="_blank"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Hierarchically porous Zn&lt;inf&gt;0.76&lt;/inf&gt;Co&lt;inf&gt;0.24&lt;/inf&gt;S/CoS heterostructures confined in N,S-co-doped carbon as high-performance anodes for sodium-ion batteries</span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 8 8" height="20" aria-label="Opens in new window" class="icon icon-arrow-up-right-tiny arrow-external-link"><path d="M1.12949 2.1072V1H7V6.85795H5.89111V2.90281L0.784057 8L0 7.21635L5.11902 2.1072H1.12949Z"></path></svg></span></a></h3><div>2024, New Journal of Chemistry</div></div><div class="buttons"></div><div class="u-display-none" aria-hidden="true"><div class="abstract u-margin-xs-top u-margin-m-bottom u-font-serif" id="reference-abstract"></div></div></li></ul></div></div></section></div><div class="Footnotes text-xs"><dl class="footnote"><dt class="footnote-label"><a class="anchor u-padding-s-hor u-padding-xs u-display-inline-block anchor-primary" href="#bfn1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text"><sup>1</sup></span></span></a></dt><dd class="footnote-detail u-padding-xs-top"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="ntpara0010">These authors contributed equally to this work.</div></dd></dl></div><a class="anchor abstract-link anchor-primary" href="/science/article/abs/pii/S0378775324011388"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">View Abstract</span></span></a><div class="Copyright"><span class="copyright-line">© 2024 Elsevier B.V. All rights are reserved, including those for text and data mining, AI training, and similar technologies.</span></div></article><div class="u-display-block-from-md col-lg-6 col-md-8 pad-right     const pendoData = {"visitor":{"pageName":"SD:product:journal:article","pageType":"CP-CA","pageProduct":"SD","pageLanguage":"en","pageEnvironment":"prod","accessType":"ae:ANON_IP","countryCode":"GB"},"account":{"id":"ae:11279","name":"ae:Imperial College London"},"events":{}};;
    pendoData.events = {
      ready: function () {
        pendo.addAltText();

    function runPendo(data, options) {
  const {
    firstDelay,
    maxRetries,
    urlPrefix,
    urlSuffix,
    apiKey
  } = options;
  (function (apiKey) {
    (function (p, e, n, d, o) {
      var v, w, x, y, z;
      o = p[d] = p[d] || {};
      o._q = [];
      v = ['initialize', 'identify', 'updateOptions', 'pageLoad'];
      for (w = 0, x = v.length; w < x; ++w) (function (m) {
        o[m] = o[m] || function () {
          o._q[m === v[0] ? 'unshift' : 'push']([m].concat([].slice.call(arguments, 0)));
        };
      })(v[w]);
      y = e.createElement(n);
      y.async = !0;
      y.src = urlPrefix + apiKey + urlSuffix;
      z = e.getElementsByTagName(n)[0];
      z.parentNode.insertBefore(y, z);
    })(window, document, 'script', 'pendo');
    pendo.addAltText = function () {
      var target = document.querySelector('body');
      var observer = new MutationObserver(function (mutations) {
        mutations.forEach(function (mutation) {
          if (mutation?.addedNodes?.length) {
            if (mutation.addedNodes[0]?.className?.includes("_pendo-badge")) {
              const badge = mutation.addedNodes[0];
              const altText = badge?.attributes['aria-label']?.value || 'Feedback';
              const pendoBadgeImage = pendo.dom(`#${badge?.attributes?.id.value} img`);
              if (pendoBadgeImage.length) {
                pendoBadgeImage[0]?.setAttribute('alt', altText);
              }
            }
          }
        });
      });
      var config = {
        attributeFilter: ['data-layout'],
        attributes: true,
        childList: true,
        characterData: true,
        subtree: false
      };
      observer.observe(target, config);
    };
  })(apiKey);
  (function watchAndSetPendo(nextDelay, retryAttempt) {
    if (data.visitor.id) {
      console.debug(`initializing pendo`);
      pendo.initialize(data);
    } else if (typeof pageDataTracker === 'object' && typeof pageDataTracker.getVisitorId === 'function' && pageDataTracker.getVisitorId()) {
      data.visitor.id = pageDataTracker.getVisitorId();
      console.debug(`initializing pendo`);
      pendo.initialize(data);
    } else {
      if (retryAttempt > 0) {
        return setTimeout(function () {
          watchAndSetPendo(nextDelay * 2, retryAttempt - 1);
        }, nextDelay);
      }
      pendo.initialize(data);
      console.debug(`gave up ... pendo initialized`);
    }
  })(firstDelay, maxRetries);
}
    window.addPendoScript = () => {
      runPendo(pendoData, {
        firstDelay: 100,
        maxRetries: 5,
        urlPrefix: 'https://cdn.pendo.io/agent/static/',
        urlSuffix: '/pendo.js',
        apiKey: 'd6c1d995-bc7e-4e53-77f1-2ea4ecbb9565',
      });
      window.addPendoScript = () => {};
    };
    addEventListener('load', () => window.addPendoScript());
  </script>
