To improve conductivity and structural stability, pitch solution was infiltrated into yolk-shell structured cobalt sulfoselenide microsphere, and finally, pitch-derived carbon-coated cobalt sulfoselenide yolk-shell microsphere (denoted as CoSSe-YS@C) was successfully synthesized by a simple heat treatment process. Additionally, to prepare a comparative sample, cobalt sulfoselenide yolk-shell microsphere was also subjected to the same post-treatment process without carbon coating. This post-treated sample was referred to as CoSSe-YS.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="sch1"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0378775324011388-sc1.jpg" height="346" alt="Scheme 1" aria-describedby="cap0050"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0378775324011388-sc1_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (1MB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (1MB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0378775324011388-sc1.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cap0050"><p id="fspara0050"><span class="label">Scheme 1</span>. Schematic illustrations of formation mechanism for heteroatom-doped cobalt sulfoselenide yolk-shell microspheres with and without pitch-derived carbon coating process.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0075">The crystal structure and morphological characteristics of sprayed precursor cobalt oxide yolk-shell microspheres were displayed in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S2</span></span></a>. The XRD data in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S2a</span></span></a> exhibited the formation of Co<sub>3</sub>O<sub>4</sub> phase after spray pyrolysis process. On the other hand, there were no the peaks of other phases related to heteroatoms. It revealed that heteroatoms were successfully doped into Co<sub>3</sub>O<sub>4</sub> yolk-shell microsphere during the spray pyrolysis process. The overall microspheres had yolk-shell structure as exhibited in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S2b</span></span></a>. The size deviation of the microspheres arose from the size deviation of the droplets generated from the droplet generator. The high magnified SEM in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S2c</span></span></a> showed yolk part was well formed inside the shell. The prepared cobalt oxide yolk-shell microsphere was transformed into a cobalt sulfoselenide yolk-shell microsphere through post-treatment with S and Se sources. Subsequently, after an additional post-treatment step, CoSSe-YS was fabricated. The morphological characteristics of CoSSe-YS are depicted in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig1" name="bfig1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 1</span></span></a>. The low-magnified SEM image in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig1" name="bfig1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 1</span></span></a>a showed almost similar yolk-shell structure comparing to sprayed precursor microspheres as displayed in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S2b</span></span></a>. The TEM image in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig1" name="bfig1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 1</span></span></a>b obviously demonstrated the yolk-shell structure formation. Despite the phase transformation of metal oxide to metal chalcogenide by heat treatment, the collapse of the yolk-shell structure by crystal growth was not observed as shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig1" name="bfig1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 1</span></span></a>c. Small-sized cobalt sulfoselenide nanocrystals, which were consisting of yolk-shell structure, offered mutual crystal-growth inhibition by the alloying reaction. The high-resolution TEM (HR-TEM) image in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig1" name="bfig1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 1</span></span></a>d indicated a spacing of 0.27&nbsp;nm, smaller than the standard lattice fringe associated with the (101) plane of Co<sub>0.85</sub>Se. This result indicates successful incorporation of sulfur in the crystal lattice of Co<sub>0.85</sub>Se, where sulfur partially substitutes the Se<sup>2+</sup> ions. The selected area electron diffraction (SAED) pattern in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig1" name="bfig1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 1</span></span></a>e, also verified the presence of a Co<sub>0.85</sub>Se phase partially doped with sulfur. The elemental mapping images presented in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig1" name="bfig1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 1</span></span></a>f verify an even dispersion of cobalt sulfoselenide nanocrystals within the yolk-shell structure. Additionally, the mapping images in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S3</span></span></a> also indicate the homogeneous distribution of other dopants (such as Ni, Si, W, and Al) within the cobalt sulfoselenide structure. Furthermore, the atomic ratio of sulfur/selenium in CoSSe-YS was determined as 0.65, based on the EDX results in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S4</span></span></a> and <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Table S1</span></span></a>. It is important to note that the high concentration of carbon observed in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Table S1</span></span></a> is attributed to the carbon grid used during the TEM analysis. Since the yolk-shell structure was developed through a carbon combustion mechanism, the presence of the carbon component within CoSSe was found to be minimal. Additionally, the EDX results showed that various dopants present in trace amounts were almost undetectable.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="fig1"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0378775324011388-gr1.jpg" height="671" alt="Fig. 1" aria-describedby="cap0010"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0378775324011388-gr1_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (2MB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (2MB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0378775324011388-gr1.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cap0010"><p id="fspara0010"><span class="label">Fig. 1</span>. Morphological characteristics of CoSSe-YS: (a) SEM image, (b,c) TEM images, (d) HR-TEM image, (e) SAED pattern, and (f) elemental mapping images.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0080">As mentioned above, the sprayed precursor contained various heteroatom dopants, indicating that the synthesized cobalt sulfoselenide samples also possess these dopant materials. Therefore, to investigate the elemental composition of CoSSe-YS, an inductive coupled plasma (ICP) analysis was carried out on this sample. As shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Table S2</span></span></a>, the ICP data reveal the composition of S doped cobalt selenide as well as the presence of various dopants within CoSSe-YS sample. These dopants likely stem from recycling processes such as grinding, ball milling, etc. Notably, among the dopants identified, the Na, Si, Ni elements dominate the doping ratio within CoSSe-YS. Given that CoSSe-YS@C sample is subjected to an identical thermal process after pitch solution infiltration, it's reasonable to infer that its dopant composition aligns closely with CoSSe-YS.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0085">The morphological properties of pitch-derived carbon-coated cobalt sulfoselenide yolk-shell microsphere (denoted as CoSSe-YS@C) were exhibited in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig2" name="bfig2" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig2"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a>. The low-magnified SEM and TEM images in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig2" name="bfig2" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig2"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a>a and b revealed that the yolk-shell structure was constantly retained after the heat treatment process after impregnation with the pitch solution. It demonstrated that the pitch component changed to a mesophase state and became liquefied, and at this time, it uniformly penetrated and coated by capillary action through the small pores between the nanocrystals that made up the yolk-shell microspheres. When compared to the TEM image of CoSSe-YS in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig1" name="bfig1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 1</span></span></a>c, the TEM image of CoSSe-YS@C in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig2" name="bfig2" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig2"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a>c displays a smaller crystal size on its surface. This suggests that the carbon component acted in inhibiting the crystal growth of cobalt sulfoselenide. A carbon layer coated from pitch solution on the nanocrystal surface was distinctly marked as represented by arrow in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig2" name="bfig2" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig2"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a>d. The HR-TEM image and SAED pattern in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig2" name="bfig2" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig2"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a>d and e indicated that partially sulfur-doped Co<sub>0.85</sub>Se phase was well retained. The elemental mapping images in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig2" name="bfig2" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig2"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a>f and <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">S5</span></span></a> revealed that pitch-derived carbon was uniformly coated over cobalt sulfoselenide yolk-shell microsphere, and the dopant materials are also uniformly distributed.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="fig2"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0378775324011388-gr2.jpg" height="795" alt="Fig. 2" aria-describedby="cap0015"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0378775324011388-gr2_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (2MB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (2MB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0378775324011388-gr2.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cap0015"><p id="fspara0015"><span class="label">Fig. 2</span>. Morphological characteristics of CoSSe-YS@C: (a) SEM image, (b,c) TEM images, (d) HR-TEM image, (e) SAED pattern, and (f) elemental mapping images.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0090">The X-ray diffraction (XRD) and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analyses in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig3" name="bfig3" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig3"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a> elucidated the structural characteristics and chemical states of CoSSe-YS and CoSSe-YS@C samples. The XRD patterns of CoSSe-YS and CoSSe-YS@C in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig3" name="bfig3" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig3"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>a were showed shifted peaks to the right compared to those of Co<sub>0.85</sub>Se (PDF #52–1008). It verified that the sulfur element was successfully incorporated into the Co<sub>0.85</sub>Se structure without generating additional S-containing hybrids and confirmed the partial substitution of Se atoms with smaller S atoms [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib34" name="bbib34" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib34"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">34</span></span></a>]. The mean crystallite sizes of CoSSe-YS and CoSSe-YS@C, as calculated using the Scherrer equation based on the Co<sub>0.85</sub>Se (101) peak, were determined to be 23.6&nbsp;nm and 20.3&nbsp;nm, respectively. The larger crystal size of CoSSe-YS compared to CoSSe-YS@C further supports the notion that the carbon coating had an inhibitory effect on the crystal growth during the additional heat treatment. The chemical state of sulfur doped cobalt selenide was specifically investigated by XPS measurement as shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig3" name="bfig3" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig3"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>b–e. The Co 2p spectra of CoSSe-YS@C were fitted to multiple peaks, which were coincident with Co–S (781.4 and 778.2&nbsp;eV), Co–Se (779.4 and 777.3&nbsp;eV), and satellite (denoted as Sat.), which verified the successful formation of cobalt sulfoselenide solid solution [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib35" name="bbib35" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib35"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">35</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib36" name="bbib36" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib36"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">36</span></span></a>]. In the S 2p/Se 3p spectra in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig3" name="bfig3" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig3"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>c, CoSSe-YS@C represented several peaks owing to the overlapping of S 2p<sub>1/2</sub> and S 2p<sub>3/2</sub> (162.6 and 161.2&nbsp;eV) and Se 3p<sub>1/2</sub> and Se 3p<sub>3/2</sub> (165.6 and 159.7&nbsp;eV) spectra, indicating the presence of both Co–S and Co–Se bonds [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib37" name="bbib37" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib37"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">37</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib38" name="bbib38" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib38"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">38</span></span></a>]. In the high-resolution Se 3d spectrum shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig3" name="bfig3" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig3"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>d, CoSSe-YS@C showed four peaks corresponding to the Co–Se bonding: Se 3d<sub>3/2</sub> and Se 3d<sub>5/2</sub> (54.3 and 53.3&nbsp;eV) and Co 3p<sub>1/2</sub> and Co 3p<sub>3/2</sub> (59.4 and 58.4&nbsp;eV) [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib39" name="bbib39" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib39"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">39</span></span></a>]. The Se–O bond (60.5&nbsp;eV) was corresponded to Co selenite phase, which was formed by the partial oxidation of cobalt sulfoselenide nanocrystals in sampling process [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib40" name="bbib40" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib40"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">40</span></span></a>]. The wide scan XPS data of CoSSe-YS@C (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S6</span></span></a>) displayed pronounced peaks corresponding to heteroatom dopants, such as Na, Ni, Si, W, and Al [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib41" name="bbib41" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib41"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[41]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib42" name="bbib42" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib42"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[42]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib43" name="bbib43" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib43"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[43]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib44" name="bbib44" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib44"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[44]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib45" name="bbib45" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib45"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[45]</span></span></a>]. The chemical state of carbon component in CoSSe-YS@C was demonstrated by XPS C 1s and Raman spectra in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig3" name="bfig3" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig3"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>e and f, respectively. The C 1s spectrum of CoSSe-YS@C represented peaks corresponding to sp<sup>2</sup>-bonded carbon (C–C), epoxy and alkoxy groups (C–O), and carbonyl and carboxylic (O–C=O) components [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib46" name="bbib46" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib46"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">46</span></span></a>]. Moreover, obvious peaks at 1354 and 1590&nbsp;cm<sup>−1</sup> in the Raman spectrum of CoSSe-YS@C, which was related to the disorder-induced feature (D band) and E<sub>2g</sub> mode of graphite (G band), were observed in the coated carbon layers. On the other hand, D and G band were not observed in CoSSe-YS [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib47" name="bbib47" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib47"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">47</span></span></a>]. To investigate the carbon content in CoSSe-YS@C, thermogravimetric (TG) analysis was performed, as shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S7</span></span></a>. The TG curve initially showed a slight weight loss of approximately 1.8&nbsp;wt%, in the below 120&nbsp;°C, which is attributed to the evaporation of moisture from the sample. As the temperature increased, the TG curve exhibited a weight increase up to 350&nbsp;°C, likely due to the partial oxidation of cobalt sulfoselenide. Subsequently, in the higher temperature region, a gradual weight loss occurred, resulting from the oxidation of cobalt sulfoselenide and the formation of cobalt oxide. Based on the ICP data (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Table S2</span></span></a>), the atomic ratio of S:Se is approximately 1:2.4. Therefore, without considering the impact of the dopants, it can be assumed that the carbon content in CoSSe-YS@C is around 30&nbsp;wt%.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="fig3"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0378775324011388-gr3.jpg" height="619" alt="Fig. 3" aria-describedby="cap0020"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0378775324011388-gr3_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (962KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (962KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0378775324011388-gr3.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cap0020"><p id="fspara0020"><span class="label">Fig. 3</span>. Crystal structure and chemical states of CoSSe-YS and CoSSe-YS@C: (a) XRD patterns, (b–e) XPS spectra corresponding to (b) Co 2p, (c) S 2p, (d) Se 3d, (e) C 1s, and (f) Raman spectra.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0095">To investigate the electrochemical reaction mechanism of cobalt sulfoselenide for SIBs, ex-situ XPS analyses were performed on CoSSe-YS electrode in both fully charged and discharged states. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig4" name="bfig4" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig4"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>a–f depict the XPS spectra of fully discharged and charged CoSSe-YS electrodes. In the initial fully discharged state of the Co 2p spectrum, a distinct peak at 777.7&nbsp;eV, corresponding to metallic Co phase, was showed while the other peaks at 785.7 and 780.6&nbsp;eV were attributed to CoO phase, which resulted from the oxidation of the metallic Co during sample preparation under an air atmosphere [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib13" name="bbib13" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib13"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">13</span></span></a>]. Conversely, in the fully charged state, Co 2p spectrum revealed obvious peaks at 783.3/780.0 and 780.1/778.1&nbsp;eV, were coincident with Co–S and Co–Se bonds, respectively [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib35" name="bbib35" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib35"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">35</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib36" name="bbib36" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib36"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">36</span></span></a>]. The S 2p spectrum for the initial discharged state was decomposed into four peaks at 162.1/160.4 and 168.7/165.9&nbsp;eV, which were coincident with Na<sub>2</sub>S and the partially oxidized phase (SO<sub>x</sub>), respectively. On the other hand, the spectrum of fully charged state represented two main peaks located at 162.3 and 160.5&nbsp;eV, which were ascribed to Co–S bonds [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib35" name="bbib35" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib35"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">35</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib48" name="bbib48" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib48"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">48</span></span></a>]. In the Se 3d spectra, similar trends were observed for both initial discharged and charged states, as compared to the S 2p spectra. For the initial discharged state in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig4" name="bfig4" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig4"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>c, two main peaks corresponding to Na<sub>2</sub>Se were observed at 55.4/54.0&nbsp;eV, and the other peaks at 60.5/58.7&nbsp;eV were assigned to Se–O bonding due to the partial oxidation of Na<sub>2</sub>Se [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib49" name="bbib49" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib49"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">49</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib50" name="bbib50" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib50"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">50</span></span></a>]. In the Se 3d spectrum for the fully charged state (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig4" name="bfig4" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig4"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>f), four peaks at 54.0/54.9&nbsp;eV (Se 3d<sub>5/2</sub>/Se 3d<sub>3/2</sub>) and 57.0/58.5&nbsp;eV (Co 3p<sub>3/2</sub>/Co 3p<sub>1/2</sub>) could be attributed to the Co–Se bonds [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib39" name="bbib39" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib39"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">39</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib40" name="bbib40" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib40"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">40</span></span></a>]. The Na 1s spectra of discharged and charged electrodes (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S8</span></span></a>) displayed peaks at 1071.2&nbsp;eV, corresponding to the Na<sub>2</sub>CO<sub>3</sub> phase [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib51" name="bbib51" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib51"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">51</span></span></a>]. This is likely due to the SEI layer for the initial discharging process. Notably, the intensity of these peaks were reduced after the charging process, which can be ascribed to the electrocatalytic effect by metallic Co [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib52" name="bbib52" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib52"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">52</span></span></a>]. To further investigate the phase conversion <em>via</em> electrochemical reaction of CoSSe-YS electrode in both fully discharged and charged states, the ex-situ TEM analysis was performed as shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig5" name="bfig5" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig5"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a>a–d. In <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig5" name="bfig5" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig5"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a>a, fully discharge TEM image displayed distinct lattice fringes with separations of 0.20, 0.23, and 0.39&nbsp;nm, corresponding to the (111), (220), and (111) planes of metallic Co, Na<sub>2</sub>S, and Na<sub>2</sub>Se, respectively. In contrast, at the fully charged state, the HR-TEM image in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig5" name="bfig5" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig5"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a>b shows lattice fringes separated by 0.29 and 0.26&nbsp;nm, corresponding to the (311) and (101) crystal planes of Co<sub>9</sub>S<sub>8</sub> and Co<sub>0.85</sub>Se phases, respectively. The SAED patterns of the initial discharged electrode coherent metallic Co, Na<sub>2</sub>Se, and Na<sub>2</sub>S, while in the initial charge state diffraction rings correspond to Co<sub>9</sub>S<sub>8</sub> and Co<sub>0.85</sub>Se phases.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="fig4"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0378775324011388-gr4.jpg" height="632" alt="Fig. 4" aria-describedby="cap0025"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0378775324011388-gr4_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (1MB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (1MB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0378775324011388-gr4.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cap0025"><p id="fspara0025"><span class="label">Fig. 4</span>. XPS spectra showcasing the chemical states of CoSSe-YS electrode during the initial cycle. The spectra present (a,c,e) in the fully discharged state and (b,d,f) in the fully charged state: (a,b) Co 2p, (c,d) S 2p, and (e,f) Se 3d.</p></span></span></figure><figure class="figure text-xs" id="fig5"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0378775324011388-gr5.jpg" height="537" alt="Fig. 5" aria-describedby="cap0030"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0378775324011388-gr5_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (1MB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (1MB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0378775324011388-gr5.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cap0030"><p id="fspara0030"><span class="label">Fig. 5</span>. HR-TEM images and SAED patterns of CoSSe-YS electrode in the initial cycle. Displaying fully (a,c) discharged and (b,d) charged states: (a,b) HR-TEM images, and (c,d) SAED patterns.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0100">The electrochemical properties of coblat sulfoselenide for SIB are depicted in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig6" name="bfig6" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig6"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 6</span></span></a>. The electrochemical reaction mechanism of cobalt sulfoselenide anode was also investigated using cyclic voltammetry (CV) in 0.001–3.0&nbsp;V at a 0.1&nbsp;mV&nbsp;s<sup>−1</sup> for the initial five cycles. The CV curves of CoSSe-YS and CoSSe-YS@C electrodes as shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig6" name="bfig6" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig6"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 6</span></span></a>a and b exhibited an analogous tendency. During the initial discharging process, both electrodes displayed a pronounced reduction peak at 0.67&nbsp;V. This peak was coincident with the conversion reaction from cobalt sulfoselenide to metallic Co, Na<sub>2</sub>S, and Na<sub>2</sub>Se [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib53" name="bbib53" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib53"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">53</span></span></a>]. In the subsequent charging process, the distinct anodic peak around 1.9&nbsp;V was ascribed to the regeneration of Co<sub>0.85</sub>Se and Co<sub>9</sub>S<sub>8</sub>, indicating the creation of cobalt sulfide/selenide hetero-interfaces after initial cycle [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib53" name="bbib53" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib53"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">53</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib54" name="bbib54" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib54"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">54</span></span></a>]. Notably, both electrodes exhibited minor redox peaks near 0&nbsp;V, which is an abnormal phenomenon for metal chalcogenide anode materials. These peaks are attributed to the insertion/extraction of sodium ions into the Super-P component included in the electrode [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib55" name="bbib55" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib55"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">55</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib56" name="bbib56" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib56"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">56</span></span></a>]. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S9</span></span></a> revealed that in the absence of Super-P, these peaks were not observed, confirming their relation to sodium insertion/extraction in Super-P. The electrochemical reaction of CoSSe electrodes during the initial discharge and charge process confirmed by CV analysis was consistent with the ex-situ XPS and TEM results. Moreover, considering the previous literatures about cobalt chalcogenide anodes for SIBs, the reaction mechanism of CoSSe anode after second cycle can be described as follows [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib57" name="bbib57" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib57"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">57</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib58" name="bbib58" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib58"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">58</span></span></a>]:<span class="display"><span id="ufd1" class="formula"><span>9.85Co&nbsp;+&nbsp;Na<sub>2</sub>Se&nbsp;+&nbsp;8Na<sub>2</sub>S ↔ Co<sub>0.85</sub>Se&nbsp;+&nbsp;Co<sub>9</sub>S<sub>8</sub>&nbsp;+&nbsp;18 Na<sup>+</sup>&nbsp;+&nbsp;18e<sup>-</sup></span></span></span>In <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig6" name="bfig6" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig6"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 6</span></span></a>c, the plateaus in the initial cycle are matched with the reduction and oxidation peaks in the CV curves well. It observed that the initial discharge and charge capacity of CoSSe-YS were 769&nbsp;mA&nbsp;h&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup> and 581&nbsp;mA&nbsp;h&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup>, respectively. Notably, despite the presence of carbon content, CoSSe-YS@C displayed similar capacities, registering at 804&nbsp;mA&nbsp;h&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup> and 597&nbsp;mA&nbsp;h&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup> for discharge and charge, respectively. This can be ascribed to the smaller crystal size of CoSSe-YS@C, which enhances its electrochemical reactivity with Na-ions [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib47" name="bbib47" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib47"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">47</span></span></a>]. To highlight the superior properties of cobalt sulfoselenide anode, cobalt sulfide, and cobalt selenide yolk-shell microspheres (referred to as CoS-YS and CoSe-YS, respectively) were synthesized, and their electrochemical properties were compared with CoSSe-YS anode. These anodes were fabricated by mixing heteroatom-doped cobalt oxide yolk-shell microspheres with sulfur and selenium sources, respectively, followed by the same heat treatment process. As shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S10a</span></span></a>, the XRD data of prepared samples exhibited characteristic peaks corresponding to Co<sub>9</sub>S<sub>8</sub> (PDF #75–2023) and CoSe<sub>2</sub> (PDF #88–1712). Furthermore, SEM images in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S10b</span></span></a> and c indicated that, although CoS-YS exhibited more crystal growth during the heat treatment process compared to CoSSe-YS, it still maintained the yolk-shell structure. Additionally, the SEM images in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S10d</span></span></a> and e demonstrated that CoSe-YS underwent significant crystal growth during the heat treatment process, leading to a complete collapse of the yolk-shell structure. This indicates that the inhibitory effect on crystal growth due to sulfur doping is essential for maintaining the yolk-shell microsphere structure in cobalt sulfoselenide nanocrystals. The rate capabilities of these anodes were compared, as displayed in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig6" name="bfig6" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig6"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 6</span></span></a>d. CoSSe-YS@C represented reversible discharge capacities of 620, 580, 548, 491, 432, 387, and 353&nbsp;mA&nbsp;h&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup> at 0.2, 0.5, 1, 2, 3, 4, and 5&nbsp;A&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup> respectively. The capacity was recovered to 607&nbsp;mA&nbsp;h&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup> when the current density was reduced back to 0.2&nbsp;A&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup>. The discharge capacities of CoSSe-YS, CoS-YS, and CoSe-YS at a current density of 5&nbsp;A&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup> were 348, 276, and 116&nbsp;mA&nbsp;h&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup>, respectively. This performance can be partly explained by the transformation of cobalt sulfoselenide nanocrystals into ultrafine Co nanocrystals with Na<sub>2</sub>S/Na<sub>2</sub>Se matrix. Previous studies indicate that this Na<sub>2</sub>S/Na<sub>2</sub>Se heterostructure facilitates a rapid diffusion of Na-ions, enhancing the rate capabilities [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib59" name="bbib59" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib59"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">59</span></span></a>]. Therefore, the superior rate capabilities of CoSSe-YS compared to CoS-YS and CoSe-YS can likely be attributed to its smaller nanocrystals and the formation of heterointerface structures. Additionally, CoSSe-YS@C electrode, as illustrated in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig6" name="bfig6" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig6"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 6</span></span></a>e, maintains stable and impressive rate capability of 140&nbsp;mA&nbsp;h&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup> even at the high current density of 15&nbsp;A&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup>. Notably, despite the presence of a surface carbon layer, CoSSe-YS and CoSSe-YS@C showed similar rate capabilities, suggesting that the carbon layer on the CoSSe-YS anode does not significantly enhance electrochemical kinetics. In this study, the pitch-derived carbon layer underwent low-temperature carbonization at 500&nbsp;°C, thus it is anticipated to exhibit low electronic conductivity. However, when considering cycle stability, the carbon coating layer may contribute substantially to performance improvement. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig6" name="bfig6" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig6"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 6</span></span></a>f illustrates the cycling performances of these anode materials at a 0.2&nbsp;A&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup>. CoSSe-YS outperformed CoS-YS and CoSe-YS in terms of cycling stability, indicating that the smaller crystal size in CoSSe-YS aids in effectively regulating stress during cycling [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib60" name="bbib60" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib60"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">60</span></span></a>]. However, despite its small-sized cobalt sulfoselenide nanocrystals, CoSSe-YS still showed a gradual decrease in capacity over 100 cycles. In contrast, CoSSe-YS@C maintained excellent cycling stability, highlighting the ability of the carbon layer coating to effectively accommodate volumetric stress during repeated cycling. The discharge capacity of CoSSe-YS@C demonstrated a minor decrease from 636 to 560&nbsp;mA&nbsp;h&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup> from the 2nd to the 100th cycle, with a capacity retention of 88&nbsp;%. These results align with the differences in structural morphologies observed in cycled electrodes, as depicted in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig6" name="bfig6" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig6"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 6</span></span></a>g–j. The SEM image shows that CoSSe-YS@C electrode maintained good stability, whereas other electrodes exhibited significant structural breakdown. The ex-situ electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) measurements, which was carried out before cycling and after 100 cycles, further verified the superiority of the surface carbon layer in enhancing the structural integrity of the anode material. As depicted in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S11a</span></span></a>, the resistance of fresh electrodes showed significant values, primarily due to the insufficient aging time of electrodes. Notably, the fresh state of CoSSe-YS@C electrode exhibited higher resistance due to the additional surface carbon layer, which further delayed the aging process. However, as shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S11b</span></span></a>, this carbon layer enhanced structural stability, thereby maintaining a smaller resistance value over 100 cycles and preserving structural integrity. In contrast, the EIS data of CoSSe-YS electrode after 100 cycles revealed a higher resistance, which is likely attributable to the thick SEI layer due to continuous structural degradation during repeated cycling.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="fig6"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0378775324011388-gr6.jpg" height="533" alt="Fig. 6" aria-describedby="cap0035"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0378775324011388-gr6_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (1MB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (1MB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0378775324011388-gr6.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cap0035"><p id="fspara0035"><span class="label">Fig. 6</span>. CV curves of (a) CoSSe-YS and (b) CoSSe-YS@C electrodes, and (c) their initial discharge/charge curves. Electrochemical properties of CoSSe-YS, CoSSe-YS@C, CoS-YS, and CoSe-YS electrodes: (d) Rate performances, (e) Rate performance of CoSSe-YS@C at various current densities (0.2–15&nbsp;A&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup>), (f) Cycle performances at a current density of 0.2&nbsp;A&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup>, and (g–j) their SEM images after 100 cycles.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0105">To explore the impact of heteroatom doping in CoSSe-YS anode, a phase-pure cobalt sulfoselenide yolk-shell microsphere (referred to as P-CoSSe-YS) was fabricated using identical spray pyrolysis and post-treatment processes. For this, the spray solution was made by dissolving same concentration of cobalt salt and sucrose, without the addition of any other heteroatoms. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S12a</span></span></a> and b show that the synthesized P-CoSSe-YS exhibited a yolk-shell structure, and its XRD data (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S12c</span></span></a>), similar to that of CoSSe-YS, revealed peaks shifted to the right compared to Co<sub>0.85</sub>Se (PDF #52–1008). However, compared to CoSSe-YS, P-CoSSe-YS's XRD peaks were slightly shifted towards higher diffraction angles, as shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S12d</span></span></a>. This suggests that the doping with other metals, which are byproducts from the recycling process, leads to lattice expansion in the cobalt sulfoselenide structure. As reported in the previous literature, this expanded lattice structure benefits the rapid diffusion of Na-ions, thus enhancing the material's electrochemical properties [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib61" name="bbib61" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib61"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">61</span></span></a>]. Consequently, as shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S13</span></span></a>, P-CoSSe-YS exhibits a significant difference in rate capability compared to CoSSe-YS. At a 5&nbsp;A&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup>, P-CoSSe-YS represented a reversible discharge capacity of 233&nbsp;mA&nbsp;h&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup>. This indicates that heteroatom doping within the cobalt sulfoselenide nanocrystals markedly enhances the rate performance.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0110">To investigate the practical application for the developed material, a full cell test was conducted to evaluate its performance under realistic operating conditions. Prussian blue (PB) was selected as the cathode material, and its synthesis process was referenced from the previous study [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib62" name="bbib62" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib62"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">62</span></span></a>]. As shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S14</span></span></a>, the prepared PB exhibited micro-sized cube morphologies, and the X-ray diffraction (XRD) data showed sharp peaks corresponding to the face-centered cubic phase, confirming the successful synthesis of the PB cathode. Firstly, the half-cell test of the PB cathode was conducted, as depicted in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S15a and b</span></span></a>. The potential profile of the PB cathode exhibited distinct potential plateaus during the charging/discharging processes, which are consistent with typical PB cathode behavior [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib62" name="bbib62" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib62"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">62</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib63" name="bbib63" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib63"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">63</span></span></a>]. At a current density of 0.1&nbsp;A&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup>, the initial charge capacity was only 10&nbsp;mA&nbsp;h&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup>, attributed to the relatively low content of sodium-ions in the as-prepared PB cathode. Starting from the second cycle, the charge and discharge capacities were 126 and 117&nbsp;mA&nbsp;h&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup>, respectively, demonstrating a capacity retention of 99.6&nbsp;% over 50 cycles. Before assembling the full cell, the PB cathode and CoSSe-YS@C anode underwent 2 pre-cycles to address the low sodium-ion content in the fresh PB cathode and mitigate capacity loss during SEI formation in the initial cycle. As shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S15c and d</span></span></a>, the full cell exhibited a high initial charge capacity of 124&nbsp;mA&nbsp;h&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup> and a high initial Coulombic efficiency of 96&nbsp;%, attributable to the pre-cycling process. Furthermore, the full cell showed stable cycling performance over 20 cycles at a current density of 0.1&nbsp;A&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup>, indicating the promising potential of the developed anode for practical applications.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0115">To investigate the resistance of cobalt sulfoselenide during the initial discharge and charge process, in-situ EIS was conducted at a 0.1&nbsp;A&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup> across the potential range of 0.001–3.0&nbsp;V, illustrated in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig7" name="bfig7" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig7"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 7</span></span></a>. The Nyquist plots, detected at particular potentials during the initial cycles, are displayed in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig7" name="bfig7" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig7"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 7</span></span></a>a and b. These plots reflect the contributions from the solution resistance (R<sub>s</sub>), the interfacial layer related to the Solid Electrolyte Interphase (SEI) layer (R<sub>sei</sub>), and the charge transfer resistance (R<sub>ct</sub>). The changes in the total resistance (R<sub>tot</sub>&nbsp;=&nbsp;R<sub>s</sub>&nbsp;+&nbsp;R<sub>sei</sub>&nbsp;+&nbsp;R<sub>ct</sub>) during the first cycle, captured by in-situ EIS at selected potentials, are indicated by the colored dots in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig7" name="bfig7" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig7"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 7</span></span></a>c and d. During the initial discharging process, the two electrodes demonstrated a significant reduction in R<sub>tot</sub> until 1.0&nbsp;V. This phenomenon is likely attributed to aging of sodium ions, indicating gradual electrolyte penetration during the initial stage of the discharging process [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib64" name="bbib64" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib64"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">64</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib65" name="bbib65" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib65"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">65</span></span></a>]. As the discharging process continued in subsequent stages, the volume expansion resulting from the electrochemical reaction of CoSSe and the generation of SEI layers contributed to an increase in electrode resistance [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib13" name="bbib13" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib13"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">13</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib66" name="bbib66" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib66"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">66</span></span></a>]. However, the R<sub>tot</sub> values were gradually decreased as the potential decreased from 1 to 0.001&nbsp;V. It can be attributed to the conversion of large CoSSe nanocrystals to ultrafine metallic Co nanocrystals with Na<sub>2</sub>S/Na<sub>2</sub>Se matrix during the initial sodiation process [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib67" name="bbib67" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib67"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">67</span></span></a>]. This transformation had a more substantial effect on the total resistance of the electrode compared to the previously mentioned reasons, leading to a gradual decrease in R<sub>tot</sub> values. Notably, during the aging process until 1.0&nbsp;V, CoSSe-YS@C electrode demonstrated higher resistance values due to the presence of additional carbon layers. However, this carbon component plays a crucial role in alleviating the structural strain arising from volume expansion. Consequently, CoSSe-YS@C electrode showed more stable R<sub>tot</sub> variation during the conversion reaction at 0.8&nbsp;V–0.001&nbsp;V. At the subsequent charging process, the R<sub>tot</sub> of two electrodes were continuously decreased, possibly owing to the partial dissolution of SEI layers and the volume shrink induced by desodiation process [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib68" name="bbib68" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib68"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">68</span></span></a>]. Moreover, the formation of heterointerfaced nanocomposites <em>via</em> the conversion reaction from metallic Co to Co<sub>9</sub>S<sub>8</sub> and Co<sub>0.85</sub>Se enhanced the electrochemical kinetics, leading to a further decrease in R<sub>tot</sub> after 2.0&nbsp;V [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib13" name="bbib13" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib13"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">13</span></span></a>]. The variations in sodium-ion diffusion coefficients (D<sub>Na+</sub>) of the two electrodes were calculated from the sloping lines in the low-frequency domain using the following equation:<span class="display"><span id="ufd2" class="formula"><span><em>D</em><sub><em>Na+</em></sub>&nbsp;=&nbsp;0.5 (<em>RT</em>/<em>Sn</em><sup>2</sup><em>F</em><sup>2</sup><em>C</em>σ)<sup>2</sup>,</span></span></span></div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="fig7"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0378775324011388-gr7.jpg" height="612" alt="Fig. 7" aria-describedby="cap0040"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0378775324011388-gr7_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (973KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (973KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0378775324011388-gr7.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cap0040"><p id="fspara0040"><span class="label">Fig. 7</span>. In-situ EIS analysis of CoSSe-YS@C and CoSSe-YS electrodes in the initial cycle: (a,b) Nyquist plots of CoSSe-YS@C and CoSSe-YS electrodes measured at preselected potentials, (c,d) in-situ EIS graphs (R<sub>tot</sub> vs potential), and (e,f) variations in sodium-ion diffusion coefficients calculated from in-situ EIS data.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0120">The information of parameter values can be found in the previous literature [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib69" name="bbib69" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib69"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">69</span></span></a>]. As shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig7" name="bfig7" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig7"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 7</span></span></a>e and f, both electrodes exhibited a similar behavior during the initial cycle. During the initial discharging process, the S doped CoSSe crystals underwent a transformation into ultrafine Co nanocrystals distributed within a Na<sub>2</sub>S/Na<sub>2</sub>Se composite matrix. These species have higher sodium-ion diffusivity compared to CoSSe due to lower crystallinity and weaker Na–S/Na–Se ionic bonds [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib66" name="bbib66" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib66"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">66</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib70" name="bbib70" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib70"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">70</span></span></a>]. Specifically, the hetero-interface of Na<sub>2</sub>S/Na<sub>2</sub>Se serves as a rapid pathway for the diffusion of sodium-ions, further enhancing the sodium-ion diffusivity throughout the sodiation process [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib59" name="bbib59" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib59"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">59</span></span></a>]. Consequently, the D<sub>Na&nbsp;+</sub>&nbsp;values for both electrodes showed a gradual increase during the sodiation process, while demonstrating a steady decrease during the desodiation. It is noteworthy that, compared to CoSSe-YS electrode, in the discharging process, CoSSe-YS@C electrode displayed a rapid increase in D<sub>Na&nbsp;+</sub>&nbsp;starting from the conversion reaction around 0.8&nbsp;V of CoSSe, and maintained a stable D<sub>Na&nbsp;+</sub>&nbsp;variation until 1.8&nbsp;V in the charging process before the regeneration of Co<sub>0.85</sub>Se/Co<sub>9</sub>S<sub>8</sub>. This could be ascribed to the additional carbon layer surrounding the CoSSe crystals, which effectively accommodates the structural strain induced by the phase transition during the cycling process.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0125">To clarify the sodium ion diffusion kinetics during the initial cycle, the galvanostatic intermittent titration technique (GITT) analysis was applied, as depicted in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig8" name="bfig8" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig8"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 8</span></span></a>, during the initial cycle. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig8" name="bfig8" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig8"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 8</span></span></a>a and b illustrate the profiles obtained from the GITT analysis, conducted at a 0.1&nbsp;A&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup>, with a pulse time of 10&nbsp;min and a relaxation time of 60&nbsp;min. The sodium ion diffusion coefficient (D<sub>Na+</sub>) can be calculated using the following equation:<span class="display"><span id="ufd3" class="formula"><span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-1-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><msub is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>D</mi><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>N</mi><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>a</mi><mo linebreak=&quot;badbreak&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>+</mo></mrow></msub><mo linebreak=&quot;badbreak&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>=</mo><mn is=&quot;true&quot;>4</mn><mo linebreak=&quot;badbreak&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>/</mo><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>&amp;#x3C0;</mi><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>&amp;#x3C4;</mi><msup is=&quot;true&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mo stretchy=&quot;true&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>(</mo><mfrac is=&quot;true&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><msub is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>m</mi><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>B</mi></msub><msub is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>V</mi><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>M</mi></msub></mrow><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><msub is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>M</mi><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>B</mi></msub><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>S</mi></mrow></mfrac><mo stretchy=&quot;true&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>)</mo></mrow><mn is=&quot;true&quot;>2</mn></msup><mo is=&quot;true&quot;>&amp;#x2219;</mo><msup is="true"><mi is="true">N</mi><mi is="true">a</mi><mo linebreak="badbreak" is="true">+</mo></mrow></msub><mo linebreak="badbreak" is="true">=</mo><mn is="true">4</mn><mo linebreak="badbreak" is="true">/</mo><mi is="true">π</mi><mi is="true">τ</mi><msup is="true"><mrow is="true"><mo stretchy="true" is="true">(</mo><mfrac is="true"><mrow is="true"><msub is="true"><mi is="true">m</mi><mi is="true">B</mi></msub><msub is="true"><mi is="true">V</mi><mi is="true">M</mi></msub></mrow><mrow is="true"><msub is="true"><mi is="true">M</mi><mi is="true">B</mi></msub><mi is="true">S</mi></mrow></mfrac><mo stretchy="true" is="true">)</mo></mrow><mn is="true">2</mn></msup><mo is="true">∙</mo><msup is="true"><mrow is="true"><mo stretchy="true" is="true">(</mo><mfrac is="true"><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">Δ</mo><msub is="true"><mi is="true">E</mi><mi is="true">s</mi></msub></mrow><msub is="true"><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">Δ</mo><mi is="true">E</mi></mrow><mi is="true">τ</mi></msub></mfrac><mo stretchy="true" is="true">)</mo></mrow><mn is="true">2</mn></msup></mrow></math></script></span></span></span></div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="fig8"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0378775324011388-gr8.jpg" height="395" alt="Fig. 8" aria-describedby="cap0045"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0378775324011388-gr8_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (654KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (654KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0378775324011388-gr8.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cap0045"><p id="fspara0045"><span class="label">Fig. 8</span>. (A,b) GITT potential profiles for (a) CoSSe-YS@C and (b) CoSSe-YS electrodes in the initial cycle and the corresponding sodium-ion diffusion coefficients for (c) CoSSe-YS@C and (d) CoSSe-YS.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0130">The relevant parameter values have been reported in previous study [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib71" name="bbib71" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib71"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">71</span></span></a>]. As depicted in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig8" name="bfig8" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig8"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 8</span></span></a>c and d, both electrodes showed a gradual increase in D<sub>Na&nbsp;+</sub>&nbsp;values during the discharging process, followed by a gradual decrease during the charging process. Although the D<sub>Na&nbsp;+</sub>&nbsp;values obtained from GITT and EIS measurements generally exhibited parallel trends, they presented distinct differences in absolute values. Furthermore, a slight difference in the trend was observed when comparing <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig7" name="bfig7" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig7"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 7</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig8" name="bfig8" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig8"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 8</span></span></a>c. This difference might be due to the inherent uncertainties in both techniques, as reported in the previous literature [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib72" name="bbib72" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib72"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">72</span></span></a>]. However, it's important to highlight that the D<sub>Na&nbsp;+</sub>&nbsp;values obtained <em>via</em> the GITT method also reflected increased Na-ion diffusivity due to the formation of a Na<sub>2</sub>S/Na<sub>2</sub>Se heterostructure, which contributes to the enhanced rate capabilities of cobalt sulfoselenide anodes.</div></section><section id="sec4"><h2 id="sectitle0060" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">4. Conclusions</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0135">In this research, we introduced a novel fabrication procedure for heteroatom-doped cobalt sulfoselenide yolk-shell microsphere. By employing a leaching process, spray pyrolysis, and heat treatment, yolk-shell structured microspheres comprising heteroatom-doped cobalt sulfoselenide nanocrystals were successfully synthesized. The reaction mechanism of cobalt sulfoselenide in sodium-ion batteries was thoroughly investigated through various analyses. These analyses confirmed that the formation of heterostructures, induced by the conversion reaction of cobalt sulfoselenide, leads to improved electrochemical performance. Moreover, the heteroatom doping, a result of the recycling process, leads to the expansion of cobalt sulfoselenide lattice structures, enhancing Na-ion diffusion kinetics. The carbon layer on the anode surface, as a result of pitch solution infiltration, can effectively accommodate volumetric stress throughout repetitive cycling. Consequently, the heteroatom-doped cobalt sulfoselenide yolk-shell microsphere anode demonstrated outstanding cycling stability alongside remarkable rate performance for sodium-ion batteries. This novel synthesis method and the strategies for understanding the conversion reaction mechanism could be expected to apply developing various energy storage materials.</div></section><section id="sec5"><h2 id="sectitle0065" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">CRediT authorship contribution statement</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0140"><strong>Yeong Beom Kim:</strong> Writing – original draft, Investigation, Formal analysis, Data curation. <strong>Tae Ha Kim:</strong> Writing – original draft, Investigation, Formal analysis, Data curation. <strong>Seulgi Kim:</strong> Methodology, Investigation, Formal analysis. <strong>Seungo Jeong:</strong> Methodology, Investigation, Formal analysis. <strong>Yun Chan Kang:</strong> Writing – review &amp; editing, Supervision. <strong>Dongju Lee:</strong> Writing – review &amp; editing, Writing – original draft, Supervision. <strong>Gi Dae Park:</strong> Writing – review &amp; editing, Writing – original draft, Supervision, Conceptualization.</div></section></div><section id="coi0010"><h2 id="sectitle0070" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Declaration of competing interest</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0145">The authors declare that they have no known competing financial interests or personal relationships that could have appeared to influence the work reported in this paper.</div></section><section id="ack0010"><h2 id="sectitle0075" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Acknowledgments</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0150">This work was supported by a <span id="gs1">National Research Foundation of Korea</span> (NRF) grant funded by the Korea government (<span id="gs3">MEST</span>) (NRF-<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#gs3"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">2022R1F1A1070886</span></span></a>).
